question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Simple course that introduces you to the history of architecture. Lectures told like a story. 
As a Pratt student, I found it extremely difficult to comprehend the information shared in lecture and reproduce it on exams. It is a learning style I am not used to engaging with. Still a good experience though. 
The grading part of the course is very ambiguous. At this point in the semester (two weeks until it is over) we have one grade for our midterm exam that was only worth 10 points.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is an ABSOLUTE GEM! For anyone remotely interested in the built environment, this is a "must-take" course at Duke. Even if you have zero interest in architecture, I would still take this course.  Some of the most intellectual fun and curiosity I've ever experienced came in this classroom. The sketchbook component is fun and diversifies assignments in a nice way. Not super labor intensive course and the content is truly fascinating. Mid-term and final are worth a lot but they are totally manageable if you pay attention in lecture. Textbook, despite what the syllabus says, is completely optional (I didn't read it after the second week of class); but, it's a nice resource if you miss a lecture or are looking for a way to study for the midterm/final.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Appreciative of classical studies, and learning the value of understanding Roman civilization and its beginnings.
2) Being able to identify ancient buildings and artifacts and connecting them with a historical timeline, their importance, their usage, and their development. 
3) Not being afraid of new places. This is my first time traveling abroad. I have never left the US before, much less felt a new culture. I was very afraid at first, but this course has taught me that I am able to be independent in a new cultural setting. My instructors were amazing guides as well, and support was there when needed. I have learned a lot about myself in this course, and independence is something I have learned that I truly do have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned several new skills in this course. I am now able to connect historical events and figures to archeological and textual evidence. I can notice different styles of cement, frescos, columns, villas, pottery, and statues from the ancient world, dating from the Etruscans through the Hellenistic period and into ancient Rome. I learned how to recognize mythological themes in archeological sights. I also learned how to compare various burial methods, banqueting styles, and gender roles as they changed throughout Roman history. I know to challenge textual accounts of events, for they might be exaggerated or biased.  
Further, this course helped me adapt to living in a new city! I learned how to compile the little Italian I know to make my way around the neighborhoods. I learned Italian dining and social customs and how to order food in restaurants. Overall, I feel that I am able to immerse myself in the new culture and experience it to its fullest potential.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned an incredible about Roman history, literature and archaeology. I am able to identify different styles of frescos and different columns that were constructed. I am much more familiar with Roman mythology and literature. I also became very familiar with Rome, in terms of navigating the country as well as the culture and cuisine.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors are amazing. They are so full of knowledge and are excellent at teaching. The learning in this program was hands-on, meaning that in the beginning our instructors would teach us in introductions and keep on repeating. We learned through repetition and the explanation of our instructors. Later on in our course, we were able to answer their questions swiftly based on the knowledge we had gathered. Our grad TA was heavy with artifacts/buildings knowledge and our Duke faculty, Dr. C, was amazing with historical background. They complemented each other super well. I will keep the knowledge of linking things back to history for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoy how the class is lecture styled and more tour guide styled. It was much more engaging and helped retain the information y’all were teaching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were excellent. They were extremely knowledgable and passionate about the subject. They were open to all kinds of questions, even those out of the scope of ancient Rome, which encouraged excitement and curiosity in the course material and environment around us. The instructors were willing to help outside of our academic lessons as well, providing advice and recommendations for living in Rome. They created a fun and light hearted environment with minimal stress and helped facilitate a cohesive group of students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The knowledge, insight, and passion that both instructors to the class were inspiring. Their passion kept me wanting to learn more and ask questions. Even when the days were long, they were also excited to share new information with the group as well as give recommendations for places toe at and sites to see. They would ask us questions to make sure we were following along but also understood that the amount of information we were being given was often a lot and allowed us to learn at our own pace. This culture helped me learned more, especially as someone who know not retain historical dates and facts easily. The project was manageable but still gave us the opportunity to dive deep into a topic that interested us. I learned a great deal from my peers and hearing them present.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The constant movement and seeing of new things made the class super stimulating and interactive. The constant new cultural setting as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: If the free coffee offers didn’t stop I think it would help.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The instructors made the class stimulating. Their excitement and energy created a lighthearted environment in which students were encouraged to ask questions and engage. Antonio (the graduate TA) provided a very comprehensive perspective on historical sights, tying them into his archeological experiences and time spent in Italy. Further, mixing in different layers of history made the course stimulating. This particularly applied to Rome. I liked how some days consisted of ancient sights as well as churches or Renaissance exhibits. I feel like the course moved around the right amount; sufficient time was spent in Campania, Pompeii, and Rome, yet we were not in one location for too long. Allowing for free afternoons and free days provided breaks so that when we came back to learning, we were ready to experience more history.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The fact that we were able to see everything we were learning about was truly amazing. The colosseum, Imperial Palace, or Herculaneum were only more interesting and incredible due to the fact that we were walking along the streets as we were learning about it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will have an amazing experience and learn so much. If you are looking to immerse yourself in a new culture and learn deep knowledge about classical studies/old Roma. This course is for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: DO IT. Very fun, great time, best professor and grad student. 11/10 Love Italy! Go Roma!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this course enough! It has been a highlight of my Duke experience. I developed a passion for history even though I will be studying different subjects. The instructors were excellent and provided an interesting and engaging perspective on Italy, its history, and its culture. I feel like I really got to know Rome in particular, as we had chances to experience many different neighborhoods. Also, the group of students became extremely close and we shared many fun memories together.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is simply nothing like learning about Rome and Italy while in Italy. The teachers are incredible and passionate; if you have the chance to take this course, absolutely do it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of art markets, value systems, and the shady side of art and archaeology. I learned to think more critically in instances of nuance where an argument for one side or another is difficult.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical questioning, ethical questioning, research

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about loot as an all-encompassing reality (cultural, historical, and archeological settings as well as aspects of law, colonialism, oppression, war, and money). I also learned how to interpret the provenance and provenience of objects to think critically and deeply about whether it is loot. I also learned how to read complex articles, books, and journals that go into the details of an object's history and present circumstances as well as find provenance of an object who does not have much known provenance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- moral considerations surrounding the ownership of cultural heritage
- evaluation of contested institutions such as museums, archives, and libraries
- (il)legal appropriation of sacred objects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I knew a bit about looting and provenance as I worked at the nasher reorganizing their provenance files however I didn’t know the legal side of things and this class really introduced me to that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a significant amount of knowledge regarding how to approach provenance research, balance the complexities of repatriation cases, and navigate the challenging duality of legality and ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how art and artifacts have been used as symbols of power and have been stolen throughout history. I also learned about the legal side of culteral protection which I did not know much about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to look at the possession of cultural artifacts critically, how to examine and research the provenance of objects and artifacts, and how the repatriation of cultural artifacts works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the open dialogue and that the profs willingly shared their opinions!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Readings correlated to class discussion, detailed feedback given on assignments

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the variety of readings and in-depth case studies we did. I particularly liked the field trip as we got to get a hands-on experience with what we had been learning and then got to research an object connected to the place we visited. I would continue to have a variety of topics in the lectures, activities, and field trips.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- visiting lectures were excellent --> felt like a diversity of perspectives was crucial to the info
- motifs of individual looted objects that tracked along the themes we studied

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 3 different professors with 3 different areas of expertise was really helpful. We got such a developed view of the issues that way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors worked incredibly hard to facilitate our learning by routinely interjecting lectures to ask the students for active feedback. As such, we were constantly encouraged to participate and reflect on the readings that we did before classes. The occasional in-person outside speaker series were an aspect of the class that I believe should be kept for future years since it was such a delight to have such groundbreaking professionals as Patty Gerstenblith and Morag Kersel speak to our class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the form of doing background readings before lecture was useful; the research assignments also fit the themes of the course well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very interesting. I think that the reading and lecture-based structure worked well. The professors were all very knowledgable and looked to help the students succeed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like the variety of assignments.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Assignment expectations being made more clear

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More student participation and engagement would have made this course more stimulating. Sometimes, the lectures went on the whole class without much student participation at all, which, no matter how interesting, I find hard to concentrate on. I wish as well there was less coverage on the law and specific dates and times of discovery and more on the rich and complex histories and relationships of the object to place.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest lectures were interesting in making these problems feel real.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel that the class would've been way more intellectually stimulating if the professors had gone a little less into the minutiae of the history of the objects and more into general, ethical discussions about the implications of repatriation concerning the artifact at hand. Moreover, I felt like I needed to take a pre-law course to be adequately prepared for this class since the readings were often so lengthy and confusingly worded that they lost all sense of impact on me as a student and were, by no means, intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing the different points of view of the three professors as well as the guest lecturers, made the class very interesting. It was also stimulating to hear the professors have different areas of expertise.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics discussed in this class are very interesting and make you look at issues from various perspectives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot and come to class with fully thought-out arguments about the articles.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Would only recommend to someone with an extreme interest in course topics, course has a very Eurocentric focus overall

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very cool and unique course on looting and archeological objects. Makes you think about the acquisition and placement of objects and cultures around the world in a new way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: good intersection of a handful of topics -- will offer insight into the all three fields

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very interesting concept. I have never seen that before of having 3 teachers teach at once. I recommend taking a class like this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course could certainly be rewarding for someone with a deep interest in archaeology, manuscript studies, ancient cultures, and/or divinity studies. That said, I was sorely disappointed by the fact that it often felt more like a pre-law course or prerequisite history class rather than a supposedly fun, interactive course that I intended to take out of passion--a passion that, because of this course, I caught myself having to repeatedly remind myself why I liked this major and wanted to keep pursuing it in the first place.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You do not need a strong background in art history or religious studies to find the material very interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Japanese culture and art, which I had never had exposure to before. I learned how to give a concise presentation pitch. I learned how to explore culture through a variety of methods including architecture, fine art, food, and transportation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It taught me how to see history in physical way and how history is still present in our landscape. Architecture is imbued with cultural and political senses and so looking at the various buildings in tokyo was a really interesting way to see history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course introduced me to the vastness and diversity of the city of Tokyo. Through fashion, history, architecture, shopping, and the arts we explored how Tokyo, and global conceptions of the city, have transformed over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I think this course really emphasized multiple ways of thinking, beyond just the subject matter (Tokyo) itself
1. Visual Media Analysis
- A lot of this course focused on comparing visual media sources, and understanding their implications and can be applied in a very broad context
2. Urban Studies
- This course really nailed the various factors that make up any urban environment, and how they connect (such as social, economic and political)
3. Art Historical Analysis
- We had a lot of time focused on engaging in classic art historical analysis on various materials

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I initially decided to take this class because I have loved Tokyo and Japanese culture from a very young age, and this was in part due to anime. Although anime is great though, I learned that there is so much more that makes the city and the country what it is. I learned so much about the history and progression of different sections in Tokyo, all the way from Shitamachi to Shibuya, and I think the class did a very good job of balancing student engagement and course work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- How Tokyo changed throughout the late 19th and 20th century from the (Edo period, Meiji restoration, wartime, etc)
- Various forms of expression that have emerged from Tokyo (fashion, art, architecture, cinema etc.)
- How to synthesize different types of media, including but not limited to movies, articles, music

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to look at museum objects from the perspectives of different museum professionals, such as curators, registrar, and conservators. I learned about the process of handling and acquiring objects for a museum's collection, and the rules to be followed in that process. I learned to put myself in the shoes of a curator through the exercise of the object proposal final project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot of valuable information about object handling, museum guidelines, and writing for a museum setting. This, more specifically, included studying the different sensitivities and conservation needs of objects, understanding the rules and regulations of museum practice, and writing wall labels.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Museum Object, I learned the origins of collecting museum objects, tracing back to the fascination of collecting through travel. I learned about the meticulous care and handling required for the collection; understanding the delicate balance between preservation and accessibility. Exploring the vital role of conservators shed light on the meticulous efforts behind the scenes, preserving the objects for future generations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved being able to closely look at museum objects in different settings and in new ways beyond the exhibition halls. Great mix of lecture, discussion, and activity to break up the long class period. Very clear instruction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: definitely keep all the guest speakers. It was great to ask people your general questions about museum practices and have them give personal examples along with their answers. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a fascinating class that will have you rethink what it means for something to be art, and what it means for an institution to be a museum. You'll get a crash course on museum guidelines, object handling, and analysis by interacting with objects up close and personal. It is an awesome class with a kind and knowledgeable professor. Take this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend it as a definite must. The course offers a comprehensive exploration of museum object and collection. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Prior to this class, I hadn't really explored what it meant to be a curator, and this class certainly gave me insight into the challenges of curatorial practice and exhibition-making. I also learned how to become a better reader and writer. I also learned how to think out of the box and challenge/critique international decisions behind the creation of these shows.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the implications of certain theses for exhibitions; particularly, delving into identity-based issues. Secondly, the strategy and organization behind creating exhibitions was thoroughly explored, and lastly, how exhibitions have been employed as tools for communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really enjoyed how this course imparted not taking everything at face value, and thinking critically about exhibitions even when they come from highly esteemed institutions or individuals. Inspecting the theses, curatorial processes, and public reactions to each exhibition we looked at really helped me understand the practice of curation throughout the 20th and 21st century, and see how it's evolved to become it's own discipline in the art world. The factors that go into creating exhibitions, including the history of the collections and the agency of the buildings themselves, have a much larger significance than I'd previously realized, and this course did an excellent job of analyzing each of these aspects when studying art history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about contemporary art, which is something I didn't have a great deal of knowledge on before taking this course. I learned how to critically evaluate an exhibition and connect art and curation with world events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new way of thinking and understanding. Also, this class provided a new lense of history for me, a way to view society through established art.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: modern land mark exhibitions, curatorial theory and its development, exhibition design

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class mainly focused on the way curatorial practice has developed and emerged within different cultures over time. I learned about curatorial mistakes of the past—and how today, curators aim to avoid and rectify such errors. Finally, the course highlighted many pieces of art and artists that I hadn't been aware of previously.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Marshall did an excellent job making the space feel welcoming. I struggle with public speaking, but this class made me comfortable enough to participate in the discussion. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was always accessible and willing to allow students to express their opinions and thoughts throughout class. Additionally, while assignments were always clear, there was a lot of room for the students to customize their approach.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the discussion that the class would engage in. Having an assigned person who was designated to facilitate conversation and ask questions for each and every exhibition we looked at was not only engaging, but also made the discussions much deeper and fleshed out than if there were no facilitator (based on experience from other classes, there would be a lot more awkward silence). I think the structure of having a discussion after each presentation was super effective, and it paced the class nicely so none of the presentations were overwhelming or long, and the teachings from the presentations were fresh on peoples' minds during the discussions. the guest speakers and trip through the Nasher's galleries were also invigorating and a nice addition to the learning experience. I think the requiring note taking to be analog, and requesting that laptops and devices stay stowed throughout the class was also conducive to a better learning environment, as it kept people present and focused on the lesson at hand, rather than back tracking through the readings or getting distracted by everything else a laptop has to offer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was phenomenal and so far my favorite class at Duke. Professor Tripplett is very passionate about medieval castles and always makes lectures engaging and interesting, even when he was talking about history that could've been dry. What I loved about the class was the focus on learning rather than just route memorization. I feel like I actually understand the parts of castles, the Medieval Ages, and daily life. The Teams page was great. He was communicative to emails, understanding of personal situations, and course expectations were always clear. The structure was great: half history for basis and then the other half building castles in 3D modeling software. The videos and captions were great.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Some of the tutorials had complicated techniques and the labs took me longer than I expected. But Professor Tripplett is responsive on email and will stay after class if he can.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend the course! It's one of the most unique classes offered at Duke (with history, art history, and design/3D modeling components) and the way that the things you learn in class/the readings inform the work you do for the labs/final project makes it a very fun experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Try it out! If you like history this class is likely going to be a lot of fun for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is quite difficult if you don't already have a strong foundation in history or 3D modeling. Experience with one or the other would suffice, but I struggled coming in with weak backgrounds in both. My best advice is to start the labs early and dedicate enough time to just playing around with the software and making mistakes. Do your best to bridge the gap between the 3D modeling and the lecture content so you aren't going into the final project unsure of where to begin.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We were put into group projects to help with a specific arts organization, where we gained so much insight on what it is like to help with arts administration as well as policy. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The biggest stimulating factor were the fieldtrips & the semester long project. They were more dynamic and allowed us to incorporate a lot of skills we personally had. It gave us an organization or community to reach out to, which helped. I think tying the fieldtrips back to the concepts we learned was enlightening. This was most seen in the writing assignments, such as the discussion posts. There was a lot of critical thinking and realization that "oh yeah, this particular institution shows a concept we highlighted in class" or "I did not even realize this institution probably had to mull over their economics & that this affected their policy." I think the final paper was kind of shoved in there at the end, but I much prefer that over any final exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about the history of the art economy in Europe and throughout the world, applied economic knowledge to create models/projections about artists' sales, learned to write a long, in depth research paper about economic findings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Firstly, I gained a deep understanding of the evolution of art markets throughout time. In addition, I developed skills in data analysis and statistical methods through the group project. Lastly, I became more critical of widely held and broad perspectives that people hold on art markets and art auctions through the learning of survivorship bias.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the intersection of quantitative economic research and art history
2) I learned about the early rise of art markets by delving into the historical markets of Antwerp, 19th-century Paris, and Amsterdam
3) I learned about the field of cultural economics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about analyzing art, women in art history, and the importance of women in the art world as more than muses or painters.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- patronage dynamics in early modern art 
- educational and networking opportunities for early women artist 
- the way that sterotypes relating to motherhood  and household work affected early modern art

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was introduced to so many female artists but what I really enjoyed was learning about their faults. They are complex beings and as exceptional as they were they also were flawed in the same way that we celebrate male artists who are extremely problematic (Picasso…) so this was a great introduction to what women are capable of in the art world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about women in visual arts and their different roles as artists, patrons, collectors, etc.; different challenges they faced; how they have been represented historically; how traditionally gendered analyses have influenced popular narratives; and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about women artists, the contexts in which they operated, how to conduct visual analysis, and how to question existing art historical practices of telling women’s stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Visually analyzing art created by female artists, creating an art exhibit and understand museum layout, and speaking about how spotlight female artists

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I better understand now how to view art and appreciate it. I also know how to consider the history of the art when I look at it. I also better understand women's place in art history and how they were overlooked and what discrimination they faced.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about individual women artists, obstacles that they have faced throughout art history and ways in which they have met these challenges, and issues in art historical and museum practice regarding representation and treatment of women artists. The course explored many different ways in which women were involved in the visual arts in the early modern period: women as makers of art, women as patrons and collectors of art, and representations of women in the visual arts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the readings each week– they were well-organized thematically and provided a variety of angles and perspectives on each week's topic. It was interesting to compare/contrast them in our reading responses and discussion questions. The classes in the Nasher, Rubinstein Library, and Duke Gardens were a wonderful addition (especially the Rubinstein Library– I loved being able to engage with primary sources that were right in front of us!). Professor Hogan was always kind, understanding, and approachable and wanted her students to be comfortable and included in class, which resulted in a great learning environment. I also just want to say that this was a wonderful idea for a course and I hope that it is routinely offered in the future so that many more students can learn about this interesting and valuable topic!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The students had a mix of experience with art history and/or seminar classes—some were art history majors, others were just trying to get their ALP code, and others were somewhere in between—and everyone seemed to get a lot out of the class, which was great.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

It was also very easy to raise your hand and ask questions- most professors would ignore you if you had your hand up until they decided they were done, but in this class I could raise my hand and get my question answered immediately, which was very engaging. Additionally, one of my favorite parts was going to the library and reading books from close to the Renaissance period. It's great because it allowed me to be personally connected with the content of the course; having a physical grasp of history is absolutely fascinating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about Roman history and why the Romans were so enraptured in spectacle.

I learned that the modern world could be comparable to the Romans

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about why the Ancient Romans had the spectacles they had such as the gladiator fights, beast hunts, and chariot races. Even though gladiator fights are probably the most well-known widely, especially as brutally violent, almost sadistic spectacles, they had a greater purpose in Roman society at the time. I also learned that there was a time when the Romans did not build permanent spectacle buildings but rather built temporary ones but with good reason. I have developed a better understanding of this ancient civilization in particular and this has also allowed me to be more open-minded when it comes to thinking out other cultures or civilizations doing things that may seem odd to us but make a lot of sense when you see it from their perspective.

Lastly, through our papers, I learned how to write about art, not just from a formal lens, but a theoretical and comparative lens as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Something I really valued in this course was the global scale and perspective that this course covered. I think we really learned how integrate the contexts of art into the works themselves which is very valuable. I also think that the writing tests, while sometimes stressful hahah, let us practice being able to make a concise argument in a constrained amount of time writing with pencil and paper, which is something that a is becoming more and more rare and I definitely do see the merit in it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a depth of knowledge, methods, and skills in this course that include actively reading theoretical texts related to global art history, analyzing recent non-mainstream/familiar artworks/artists/groups, and how to have an active discussion through seminar on educational art history frameworks. I also learned how to conduct a formal analysis of an artwork as well as bring two unrelated works into a conversation with one another through backing with a formal/theoretical framework. This increased by knowledge basis and completely changed how I look at artworks today in museums, including a recent visit to The Whitney that I had just a couple weeks ago.Lastly, I learned how to be an active thinker about art history and compare it to other subjects. I am not as familiar with art history as I am a social sciences (Economics/Finance) major, so learning how to interpret and understand artworks/groups in context of global history aided in my ability to understand how they relate to the development of art history and art movements overall. Even though the course was a high level of knowledge/academic, I was able to be an active participant and engage with the material.Thank you Thea for an amazing course experience and opportunity to expand my knowledge basis of my Art History minor. I was excited for this course and the learnings that I took away from the course and will reflect on these in future art experiences that I come across. - WR

I familiarized myself with theories that work as foundations of art movements and exhibitions.
I learned to think more about the context of an artwork when that really plays an important role in that specific artwork.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ballard did a great job at structuring this course. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

This helped with the Canvas LMS and allowed me to concentrate on concrete topics on step at a time without getting confused.I also enjoyed the use of office hours in advance to both papers so that I can full understand the topic, paper type, and discuss with Thea my potential ideas on what to write about. The autonomy with paper selection/conversation made me excited about the course and excited to write the papers to share the knowledge that I learned. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Creative Cartography course created a highly engaging and supportive learning environment that encouraged both critical thinking and creative exploration. Professor Triplett structured the course in a way that balanced technical skill-building in map-making with deep conceptual inquiry into spatial narratives and visual storytelling. I particularly appreciated the open-ended nature of the assignments, which allowed me to align course projects with my dissertation interests on historical land use and environmental change.  The class discussions and weekly readings provided a strong theoretical foundation that challenged me to think more deeply about what maps represent—and what they omit. The feedback sessions, especially peer critiques and one-on-one check-ins, were extremely valuable for refining both the design and intent behind my maps.One of the most effective components I would recommend keeping is the scaffolded structure of the final project. It was incredibly helpful to break the process into stages (proposal, moodboard, draft, etc.), which made the final creative deliverable feel achievable and purposeful. I also found the integration of both analog and digital cartographic techniques to be pedagogically rich, and I’d encourage maintaining that blend in future iterations of the course.

response_text: I loved learning a little about cartography through our course readings outside of the lab work. I also appreciate that I was encouraged to think creatively and given plenty of freedom to design my project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it invited us to rethink maps not just as tools for representation, but as cultural, political, and artistic artifacts. The integration of critical theory with hands-on design work created a unique space to experiment and question—something I haven’t experienced in other courses. The encouragement to situate our own identities and research within our mapping projects made the work personally meaningful and conceptually rich.What made the course especially engaging was the freedom to pursue a self-directed final project. It pushed me to synthesize spatial analysis, historical research, and visual storytelling in new ways. I was able to explore how cartography can represent liminal spaces and historical erasure—central themes in my dissertation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Griebeler is an awkward professor, but the combination of his social awkwardness and enthusiasm/extensive knowledge about the subject makes the class enjoyable and chill. He starts with discussions of the readings and then facilitates seminars (led by small groups) that discuss the readings. Doing it that way changed class dynamics and freshened things up, providing breaks to students in terms of workload. His required papers are pretty short but you learn quite a bit from them: his grading is helpful but not harsh. He wants you to learn and it shows (e.g., giving us a crash course on French, drawing plants, and show-and-tell presentations about modern depictions of Medusa). I also loved the trips to the museum and herbarium! He does not make his class monotonous and his teaching adapts to his class and what his class needs to learn. He also brought snacks to class (2 hours long), which helped students who skipped breakfast. Super kind guy, will take another class with him if I can.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Appreciative of classical studies, and learning the value of understanding Roman civilization and its beginnings.
2) Being able to identify ancient buildings and artifacts and connecting them with a historical timeline, their importance, their usage, and their development. 
3) Not being afraid of new places. This is my first time traveling abroad. I have never left the US before, much less felt a new culture. I was very afraid at first, but this course has taught me that I am able to be independent in a new cultural setting. My instructors were amazing guides as well, and support was there when needed. I have learned a lot about myself in this course, and independence is something I have learned that I truly do have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to better analyze old rocks. I learned how to pick out key features of certain people in paintings and statues. I learned how to order coffee in italian.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned several new skills in this course. I am now able to connect historical events and figures to archeological and textual evidence. I can notice different styles of cement, frescos, columns, villas, pottery, and statues from the ancient world, dating from the Etruscans through the Hellenistic period and into ancient Rome. I learned how to recognize mythological themes in archeological sights. I also learned how to compare various burial methods, banqueting styles, and gender roles as they changed throughout Roman history. I know to challenge textual accounts of events, for they might be exaggerated or biased.  
Further, this course helped me adapt to living in a new city! I learned how to compile the little Italian I know to make my way around the neighborhoods. I learned Italian dining and social customs and how to order food in restaurants. Overall, I feel that I am able to immerse myself in the new culture and experience it to its fullest potential.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned an incredible about Roman history, literature and archaeology. I am able to identify different styles of frescos and different columns that were constructed. I am much more familiar with Roman mythology and literature. I also became very familiar with Rome, in terms of navigating the country as well as the culture and cuisine.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors are amazing. They are so full of knowledge and are excellent at teaching. The learning in this program was hands-on, meaning that in the beginning our instructors would teach us in introductions and keep on repeating. We learned through repetition and the explanation of our instructors. Later on in our course, we were able to answer their questions swiftly based on the knowledge we had gathered. Our grad TA was heavy with artifacts/buildings knowledge and our Duke faculty, Dr. C, was amazing with historical background. They complemented each other super well. I will keep the knowledge of linking things back to history for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoy how the class is lecture styled and more tour guide styled. It was much more engaging and helped retain the information y’all were teaching.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were excellent. They were extremely knowledgable and passionate about the subject. They were open to all kinds of questions, even those out of the scope of ancient Rome, which encouraged excitement and curiosity in the course material and environment around us. The instructors were willing to help outside of our academic lessons as well, providing advice and recommendations for living in Rome. They created a fun and light hearted environment with minimal stress and helped facilitate a cohesive group of students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The knowledge, insight, and passion that both instructors to the class were inspiring. Their passion kept me wanting to learn more and ask questions. Even when the days were long, they were also excited to share new information with the group as well as give recommendations for places toe at and sites to see. They would ask us questions to make sure we were following along but also understood that the amount of information we were being given was often a lot and allowed us to learn at our own pace. This culture helped me learned more, especially as someone who know not retain historical dates and facts easily. The project was manageable but still gave us the opportunity to dive deep into a topic that interested us. I learned a great deal from my peers and hearing them present.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The constant movement and seeing of new things made the class super stimulating and interactive. The constant new cultural setting as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: If the free coffee offers didn’t stop I think it would help.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The instructors made the class stimulating. Their excitement and energy created a lighthearted environment in which students were encouraged to ask questions and engage. Antonio (the graduate TA) provided a very comprehensive perspective on historical sights, tying them into his archeological experiences and time spent in Italy. Further, mixing in different layers of history made the course stimulating. This particularly applied to Rome. I liked how some days consisted of ancient sights as well as churches or Renaissance exhibits. I feel like the course moved around the right amount; sufficient time was spent in Campania, Pompeii, and Rome, yet we were not in one location for too long. Allowing for free afternoons and free days provided breaks so that when we came back to learning, we were ready to experience more history.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The fact that we were able to see everything we were learning about was truly amazing. The colosseum, Imperial Palace, or Herculaneum were only more interesting and incredible due to the fact that we were walking along the streets as we were learning about it.

response_text: The course was structured in a way that had students present on the readings each week. This allowed students to gain experience synthesizing information and presenting it to a big group, but there were also some readings or concepts that I feel should have been introduced by the professor, instead (i.e. the major topics or themes that would underscore the entire semester). question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding of public arts policy decision-making

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what exactly is arts policy, various cultural institutions and its issues, leadership and value in the arts, cultural equity (audience and access, heritage and repatriation), creative placemaking, and creative economies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We reviewed case studies in arts leadership, visited local cultural organizations, and discussed the challenges facing the arts today. A central component of the course was the extended engagement with a community partner, so we developed our collaborative skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about art in a different and new context. I also learned professional skills through the service learning aspect of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cultural and arts policies, and how we can observe the phenomenons of these policies in real life. I gained insight on the impacts of cultural and arts policy, and how each action affects the communities around us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned more about all different aspects of art policy
2. Learned how the arts directly spur economic activity
3. How to collaborate professionally in a workplace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically I learned how to analysis and interpret arts policy in the real world today and apply my leadership knowledge in unique ways to make a difference both in Durham and my local community here at Duke. I learned how to critically engage with peers about arts policy and discuss with them. Lastly, I learned how to work with community partners to ensure long-term success.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I was never afraid to share my opinion, instead maybe I was more hesitant by ruminating and tweaking how I was going to say an idea. It also helped a very natural dialogue that was insightful. This is very dependent on the people in the class, though. I know there were 6-7 key yappers, but in a class with more shy people or only a few key people speaking, it would be much more anxious/forced.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We were put into group projects to help with a specific arts organization, where we gained so much insight on what it is like to help with arts administration as well as policy. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was intellectually stimulating due to its thoughtful discussions that connected theoretical concepts to real-world policies. Engaging in group work at the end of each session allowed us to apply theories in practical contexts, enhancing our understanding and retention.​

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The biggest stimulating factor were the fieldtrips & the semester long project. They were more dynamic and allowed us to incorporate a lot of skills we personally had. It gave us an organization or community to reach out to, which helped. I think tying the fieldtrips back to the concepts we learned was enlightening. This was most seen in the writing assignments, such as the discussion posts. There was a lot of critical thinking and realization that "oh yeah, this particular institution shows a concept we highlighted in class" or "I did not even realize this institution probably had to mull over their economics & that this affected their policy." I think the final paper was kind of shoved in there at the end, but I much prefer that over any final exam.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I think the only caveat was that the class felt a little long sometimes, since it was over 2 hours, but we had breaks in the middle of it. However, mostly the whole class was very stimulating and engaging.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze art deeper than what meets the eye. I learned how much of an effect art and other forms of art have on politics and social discourse. I learned that everything can be seen in a theatrical sense.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never before taken an art history class but history is not all that this class taught me. It taught me to look beyond visual aesthetics and to find the deeper meanings for why things are the way that they are. It also was helpful in giving me really great art basics, especially about religious ideas that come up frequently in art.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be analytical, curious, and appreciative. There are arts around me that I hadn't noticed before, and I'm now able to appreciate how it reflects culture and politics. I'm able to analyze better and I've gained all of these skills that will help me immensely in my STEM studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Italian, specifically Venetian culture, and had a really good time immersing myself in the local lifestyle. I learned about art and music in relation to politics and understood more of the nuance behind politics in shaping narratives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of knowledge during this course. I learned to be in th emoment, search for new things, dig down deeper into the meanings behind why artist made certain choices, how that could be political.
