response_text: I really liked the discussion-based setting of the class, the many hands-on learning experiences, and the different perspectives we got on the same topic (for example from Professor Ken and our TA, Mitch)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was very good for learning because it was very hands on and allowed me to physically experience the art for myself and allow myself to analyze it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ken was incredibly kind, thoughtful, engaging and understanding and he created an environment for all students to learn in a meaningful way. Keep it all!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors are always kind and encouraging of voices and building off of each other. When we went on excursions, they shared insights about different paintings and answered questions. I loved getting to discuss the reading in a circle as a class and hearing students' interpretations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Giving flexibility with time for us to sleep in or explore in the afternoons. I do wish there was more ways to immerse myself in learning Italian and practice interacting with locals, as it seemed that none of my classmates were interested in exploring the language very much.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: They taught us about things in class and brought us to go see them in real life, which brought the concepts and lessons to reality. It also sparked excitement when I would see the things in person.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was 10/10. The days where we were sitting in class were just as engaging and affective as they days where we got to explore beautiful museums and churches. The professor and TA's genuine interest in what we were learning made me even more excited to dive into the topics we were talking about. The class structure should, without a doubt, stay the same.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My instructor, Professor Ken Rogerson, and my TA, Mitch Moste, were extremely passionate, engaging, and intellectually challenging. They've taught me to be analytical when facing anything, and gear my thoughts toward more abstract ideas. The structure of the course was nearly perfect in mine and my peers' understanding of the material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the overall learning environment of this class because it was both structured and relaxed. There was space to go immerse myself in Venice and field trips and learn that way while also having time to commit to actual essays and presentations. I would definitely keep this method that Prof. Ken and Mitch used for this course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Every part of the learning environment was constructive to my learning. The class was a great mix between lecturing about various artists and topics and discussion about readings and class topics. The class was also regularly spaced with field trips and excursions to get up close and personal with all of the things which were being covered. The assignments were also spaced in a way that made them feel approachable. Additionally, the Instructors created an incredibly welcoming and safe environment from the very start.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In terms of class enviorment, I think that everyone being very open to the experience really helped faciitate class discussions, moreover when our class set up changed to a circle format I thought it was easier to communicate with the class in an interactive way which was a welcomed change that I would keep. Having a physical book was also a good way to help my learning so i'd keep reccomending a hard copy.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The genuine passion of both the Professor and TA was incredibly, and made this class as stimulating as it could have possibly been

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The amount of field trips and contact we had with the teacher and TA allowed me to gain a better understanding of the subject. Also, I had a teacher that was very expressive with his interest in art so it helped me become more motivated to learn it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Ken provided a ton of very interesting examples with a lot of nuance surrounding them that forced students to engage with the material in a very stimulating way.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I got to think in so many new ways and see how intertwined art and politics are beyond overtly political art. It challenged me to think more critically when viewing art and think and feel about why do I think about things the way I do.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Was interesting material about history of Venice and artists, but peers did not seem to be as engaged with course material and that dampened the experience a bit.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made it stimulating was we had very inclusive conversation in class, and we were always expected to contribute without judgment from peers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The interest that our teachers had in the topic and the real time exposure we had to the art and music we had talked about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because we analyzed past surface level understandings and grasped abstract themes artistically and politically. Professor Rogerson and TA Mitch Moste were incredible in guiding our intellect through explorations of art and politics, they encouraged us to think profoundly and intentionally.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating because we learned through a variety of environments. We went to churches in Venice and other islands/towns, as well as free time to explore cities like Florence and Verona through our own decisions. I felt that I grew a lot from it due to this sense of independence and guidance at the same time. The readings and content was also very interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because we engaged with a wide variety of readings and were encouraged to extrapolate meanings from them and pull out ideas which we found interesting. Additionally, our assignments caused us to dive deep into specific artists and artworks and decipher what makes art political and examine how its impacts are felt.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating, because the papers allowed you to explore on your own and think about different viewpoints considering time periods, and the experinces challended my world view allowing me to adopt a revitalized view of italian culture, people, food, ect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an amazing class, regardless if you are a humanities major or not, and you will learn so much about how art and politics are integrated into all aspects of our lives and history.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it. You won't regret it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is amazing. You'll learn so much in and out of the classroom. Don't be intimidated at all if you don't know a lot about art, music, politics, or Venetian history because you'll get an amazing introduction to it all.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of free time to explore and go on your own adventures! The professor (Ken) and ta (mitch) are really nice and make sure you get the full experience, you get to go to places like Doge's Palace, Uffizi in Florence, opera in Verona etc.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot, but also enjoy the time in Venice, it goes by quick.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: They should 100% take the course and that they will have teachers that care so much for them personally and about their education.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The skills you gain from intersecting and analyzing art and politics will benefit you tremendously in any area of study you wish to pursue. This class is more than valuable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this class. You will have the time of your life in Venice and really get to feel like a local in Italy. It is so rewarding to recognize the routes and buildings in Venice, the more you explore. The class is taught by the most wonderful Professor and TA, and they really support you in everything. The content is also very interesting and diverse.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course to any and every student. If someone has even a small interest in art, history, and politics, this class is perfect. Living in Venice is incredible, and I have never been in a more immersive class in terms of actively experiencing the artworks which we learn about every day. The workload is not prohibitive in the slightest, and it honestly creates a good balance to have some structure in day-to-day life while living in Venice. The course is so interesting, and I have seen more beautiful things while on this program than I could possibly recall. Both Professor Rogerson and Mitch Moste are incredible people and teachers who made this course fun and welcoming and made a foreign city feel safe and easy to navigate.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely try to be very open minded, commit to all the new experiences you are about to have, and have fun of course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of art markets, value systems, and the shady side of art and archaeology. I learned to think more critically in instances of nuance where an argument for one side or another is difficult.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Historical questioning, ethical questioning, research

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about loot as an all-encompassing reality (cultural, historical, and archeological settings as well as aspects of law, colonialism, oppression, war, and money). I also learned how to interpret the provenance and provenience of objects to think critically and deeply about whether it is loot. I also learned how to read complex articles, books, and journals that go into the details of an object's history and present circumstances as well as find provenance of an object who does not have much known provenance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- moral considerations surrounding the ownership of cultural heritage
- evaluation of contested institutions such as museums, archives, and libraries
- (il)legal appropriation of sacred objects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I knew a bit about looting and provenance as I worked at the nasher reorganizing their provenance files however I didn’t know the legal side of things and this class really introduced me to that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a significant amount of knowledge regarding how to approach provenance research, balance the complexities of repatriation cases, and navigate the challenging duality of legality and ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how art and artifacts have been used as symbols of power and have been stolen throughout history. I also learned about the legal side of culteral protection which I did not know much about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to look at the possession of cultural artifacts critically, how to examine and research the provenance of objects and artifacts, and how the repatriation of cultural artifacts works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the open dialogue and that the profs willingly shared their opinions!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Readings correlated to class discussion, detailed feedback given on assignments

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the variety of readings and in-depth case studies we did. I particularly liked the field trip as we got to get a hands-on experience with what we had been learning and then got to research an object connected to the place we visited. I would continue to have a variety of topics in the lectures, activities, and field trips.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- visiting lectures were excellent --> felt like a diversity of perspectives was crucial to the info
- motifs of individual looted objects that tracked along the themes we studied

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 3 different professors with 3 different areas of expertise was really helpful. We got such a developed view of the issues that way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors worked incredibly hard to facilitate our learning by routinely interjecting lectures to ask the students for active feedback. As such, we were constantly encouraged to participate and reflect on the readings that we did before classes. The occasional in-person outside speaker series were an aspect of the class that I believe should be kept for future years since it was such a delight to have such groundbreaking professionals as Patty Gerstenblith and Morag Kersel speak to our class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the form of doing background readings before lecture was useful; the research assignments also fit the themes of the course well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very interesting. I think that the reading and lecture-based structure worked well. The professors were all very knowledgable and looked to help the students succeed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like the variety of assignments.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Assignment expectations being made more clear

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More student participation and engagement would have made this course more stimulating. Sometimes, the lectures went on the whole class without much student participation at all, which, no matter how interesting, I find hard to concentrate on. I wish as well there was less coverage on the law and specific dates and times of discovery and more on the rich and complex histories and relationships of the object to place.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest lectures were interesting in making these problems feel real.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel that the class would've been way more intellectually stimulating if the professors had gone a little less into the minutiae of the history of the objects and more into general, ethical discussions about the implications of repatriation concerning the artifact at hand. Moreover, I felt like I needed to take a pre-law course to be adequately prepared for this class since the readings were often so lengthy and confusingly worded that they lost all sense of impact on me as a student and were, by no means, intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing the different points of view of the three professors as well as the guest lecturers, made the class very interesting. It was also stimulating to hear the professors have different areas of expertise.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics discussed in this class are very interesting and make you look at issues from various perspectives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot and come to class with fully thought-out arguments about the articles.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Would only recommend to someone with an extreme interest in course topics, course has a very Eurocentric focus overall

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very cool and unique course on looting and archeological objects. Makes you think about the acquisition and placement of objects and cultures around the world in a new way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: good intersection of a handful of topics -- will offer insight into the all three fields

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very interesting concept. I have never seen that before of having 3 teachers teach at once. I recommend taking a class like this.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course could certainly be rewarding for someone with a deep interest in archaeology, manuscript studies, ancient cultures, and/or divinity studies. That said, I was sorely disappointed by the fact that it often felt more like a pre-law course or prerequisite history class rather than a supposedly fun, interactive course that I intended to take out of passion--a passion that, because of this course, I caught myself having to repeatedly remind myself why I liked this major and wanted to keep pursuing it in the first place.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You do not need a strong background in art history or religious studies to find the material very interesting.

response_text: I would recommend this course.

response_text: The course is really not much work, but be prepared for really vague assignments, especially for the papers. Papers are "open to interpretation", but it can be hard to know what exactly he wants. It would also help to just speak to him directly, as he is really a very kind professor. The big papers can just be a little daunting when you're not sure what to write about. Other than that though, great course, I would reccomend.
